newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Four NGO workers arrested in Kabul - witnesses.
newsitem.headline: Four NGO workers arrested in Kabul - witnesses.

text.p: Four employees of the French-based charity Action Contre la Faim (Action against Hunger) have been arrested in the Afghan capital Kabul, witnesses said on Saturday.
The four men, two French expatriates and two local staff members, were being held by the Islamic Taleban militia, which seized Kabul last September.
A spokeswoman at ACF Paris headquarters confirmed the detention of expatriates Frederic Michel and Daniel Llorente, in charge of the charity's logistics in Kabul.
She said they were taken by Talebans from the United Nations compound in Kabul on Friday night but declined to give more details.
It was not immediately clear why the four had been arrested or if they were charged with any crime.
The arrests followed a lunch organised by expatriate female staff of Action Contre la Faim (ACF) for local female employees.

Witnesses said as many as 15 armed Taleban fighters entered the ACF residence at about 1:00 p.m. (0830 GMT) on Friday, arresting a cook and a security guard, searching the house and removing cameras, photographs, magazines and films.

The two expatriates were arrested early on Saturday at the United Nations International Community Association building in central Kabul -- where they were staying -- after protracted discussions between Taleban authorities and U.N. officials.
Taleban authorities have said the portrayal of images of living human beings in photographs and paintings runs counter to Islamic law.
The ACF runs a number of projects in Kabul, including nutritional surveys and an emergency children feeding programme. It has suspended the projects until the situation has been clarified.
Taleban authorities, which now control some 80 percent of the country, want to impose their strict interpretation of Islam throughout war-ravaged Afghanistan.
